{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image = Mycena cystidiosa 14367.jpg | image_width = 234px | image_caption = In [[New South Wales]], Australia | regnum = [[Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Mycenaceae]] | genus = ''[[Mycena]]'' | species = '''''M. cystidiosa''''' | binomial = ''Mycena cystidiosa'' | binomial_authority = ([[G.Stev.]]) [[E.Horak]] (1971) | synonyms_ref = | synonyms = *''Fayodia cystidiosa'' G.Stev. (1964)
*''Mycena metuloidifera'' [[Rolf Singer|Singer]] (1969) *''Mycena hispida'' Grgur. & A.A.Holland (1982) }} {{mycomorphbox | name = ''Mycena cystidiosa'' | hymeniumType=gills | capShape = conical | whichGills = adnate | stipeCharacter = bare | sporePrintColor = white | ecologicalType = saprotrophic | howEdible = unknown }} {{stack end}} '''''Mycena cystidiosa''''' is a species of [[mushroom]] in the family [[Mycenaceae]]. Described as new to science in 1964, it is known only from New Zealand and Australia. The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] have a broadly conical small white [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] up to {{convert|12|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide, with distantly spaced [[cream (color)|cream]]-coloured [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] on the underside. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is particularly long, up to {{convert|20|cm|in|0|abbr=on}}, with an abundant covering of white hairs at the base. The species is known for its abundant [[rhizomorph]]s—long, root-like extensions of [[mycelia]]. ==Taxonomy== The species was originally [[species description|described]] by [[Greta Stevenson]] in 1964 as ''Fayodia cystidiosa''. She found the [[type (biology)|type specimen]] growing in leaf litter at the [[Wellington Botanic Garden]] in June, 1949. It was transferred to the genus ''[[Mycena]]'' by [[Egon Horak]] in a 1971 publication. The fungus is [[classification (biology)|classified]] in the [[section (biology)|section]] ''Metuloidiferae'' of the genus ''[[Mycena]]''. ==Description== [[image:Mycena cystidiosa 15153.jpg|thumb|left|The cap is light brown with a dark brown umbo, and has indistinct radial grooves.]] The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is {{convert|6|–|12|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter, and light brown with dark brown [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]]. It is indistinctly grooved and fluted with a somewhat velvety texture; the margin is paler and frilled. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white beneath the [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]], [[fawn (color)|fawn]] above the gills. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are [[wikt:adnexed|adnexed]], [[cream (colour)|cream]]-coloured, some with dull pink stains. They are moderately distantly spaced apart, and covered with [[cystidia]]. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is {{convert|6|–|8|cm|in|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|1|–|2|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick, although Australian specimens have been reported to grow as long as {{convert|20|cm|in|abbr=on}}. It is cream-coloured above and brown below, with a smooth surface. The stipe is hollow, brittle, and covered densely with white hairs at the base. Extending from the stipe base are numerous lengthy white [[rhizomorph]]s that can be up to {{convert|30|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, and terminated by a small cap or knob. The rhizomorphs of are organized as linear strands of [[mycelia]] that are differentiated into an inner portion containing large diameter 'vessel' [[hypha]]e, and an outer cortex of narrow, thick-walled hyphae. The cap at the end of the strand bears strongly resembles the developing cap of immature fruit bodies. The [[spore]]s are 9–10 by 7 [[micrometre|µm]], [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]], thick-walled, with an inner wall resembling the mesh of a sieve. Although the spore surface is smooth, it appears rough because of the irregular shape of the inner wall. The type collection also contained half-sized spores, leading Stevenson to suggest that there may be two- and four-spored [[basidia]]. Cheilocystidia and pleurocystidia ([[cystidia]] on the edge and face, respectively, of the gills) are 25–40 by 8–13 µm, very abundant, thick-walled, and stain weakly amyloid in [[Melzer's reagent]]. ==Habitat and distribution== ''Mycena cystidiosa'' is a [[saprobic]] fungus—meaning it obtains nutrients by breaking down decomposing plant organic matter. Although the mushrooms are usually found on fallen leaves, it also grows on wood, utilising the small branch litter common to eucalypt forests. The species may contain the [[enzyme]]s necessary for decomposing [[lignocellulosic biomass]]. It is found in New Zealand, southwestern Australia, and [[Tasmania]]. Australian mycologist [[Bruce Fuhrer]] calls it "possibly our tallest ''Mycena''". The mushrooms generally fruit from April to June. In a study of post-fire [[Secondary succession|succession]] in a ''[[Eucalyptus regnans]]'' forest, researchers found that ''M. cystidiosa'' appeared in the third of three phases of recolonization, more than seven years after the burn. Other mycenas often found in this "mature" phase include ''[[Mycena austrofilopes|M. austrofilopes]]'', ''[[Mycena austrororida|M. austrororida]]'', and ''[[Mycena interrupta|M. interrupta]]''.
